Dear Mr. Jones:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
9/23/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers
• (1) The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each employee
and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or more hours per week for
more than 2 consecutive weeks is free from communicable tuberculosis.
Freedom from communicable tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1 year
period before employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
Five of nineteen new employee files reviewed lacked tuberculous screen prior to
hire or on the staff's first day of employment per the approved variance for the
facility.
2

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical assistance was provided regarding CCI licensing rule 400.4127 (4)
regarding staff completing varying interval checks as per reviewing the varying
interval room check logs it was noted some checks were on the ten-minute mark.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was offered regarding Social Service Supervisor and Social
Service Worker signing and dating service plans prior to sending the
service plans out to obtain parental and worker signatures.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There was 1 substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. This was within investigation report 2025SIC0000628 dated 6/9/2025
which found the facility in non-compliance of a staff showing youth inappropriate
photos and videos on their cellphone and facetiming a youth after the youth was
discharged from the facility. A corrective action plan dated 7/1/2025 was approved
that included the staff member involved being terminated from employment and
the facility installed a cellphone lock box where staff are now securing their
cellphones in the facility conference room at the beginning of their shifts and are
not allowed to have personal cellphones on their person while working.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 9 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
• 2024 Renewal: Corrective Action Plan was recorded during this reporting
period as a result of the Renewal inspection completed on 11/4/2024. This
CAP contained one violation of CCI Rule 400.4113(1)(e) in that there were
employee files reviewed lacking references. The CAP contained action
items to ensure three references were received prior to employees being
hired.
• Special Investigation 2025SIC0000509 with CAP approval date of 6/9/2025
was a result of a violation of following the facilities internal standards of
conduct policy as per interviews staff were using inappropriate language,
staff providing information to youth that was not deemed appropriate, and
staff conducting themselves unprofessional. The facility retrained staff
regarding professional behavior and trauma informed approaches, added
additional training for staff in new employee orientation to address
3

professionalism, and terminated an employee who was involved in an
incident related to unprofessionalism. The facility is currently complying with
the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor the CAP compliance
with no noted concerns.
• Special Investigation 2025SIC0000537 with CAP approval date of
6/23/2025 was a result of a violation due to the facility not completing a final
incident report within 72 hours after the incident occurred. The facility
reviewed documentation guidelines to ensure understanding of
requirements, the facility appointed two staff to approve incident reports in
MiSACWIS and review incident reports Monday through Friday daily in
management meetings. The facility is complying with the CAP action steps
and DCWLM continues to monitor the CAP compliance. The facility did
have a repeat violation after this CAP was approved, however the situation
resulted in both approved staff being out of state and the facility not
notifying the administrator regarding the incident report pending approval.
• Special Investigation 2025SIC0000567 with CAP approval date of
7/10/2025 was a result of a staff not having the ability to perform the duties
of the position due to unprofessionalism and staff failing to report suspected
abuse and/or neglect. The facility terminated the staff’s employment related
to the staff not having the ability to perform the duties of their position as
well as implemented proactive measures to include the shift supervisor
meeting with staff on every shift to ensure staff are fit to perform the
functions of the position and observe staff while on shift to ensure
appropriate language is being used. The facility also retrained staff on
reporting requirements, hung signs around the facility to remind staff of
reporting requirements, as well as implemented a new process where the
shift supervisor is documenting if any concerns have been reported to
Centralized Intake during the shift. The facility is currently complying with
the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor the CAP compliance
with no noted concerns.
• Special Investigation 2025SIC0000628 with CAP approval date of 7/1/2025
was a result of a staff not having the ability to perform the duties of the
position due to showing youth inappropriate photographs and the staff
communicating with a youth after the youth was discharged from the facility.
The facility terminated the staff and implemented new procedure for staff
not having their personal phones on shift and disciplinary steps for staff
found in violation. The facility is currently complying with the CAP action
steps, and DCWL continues to monitor the CAP compliance with no noted
concerns.
• Special Investigation 2025SIC0000644 with CAP approval date of
7/18/2025 was a result of the facility not following their own internal policy
regarding supervision and staff reporting suspected abuse and/or neglect.
The facility implemented new processes to ensure supervision is being
completed to include seating assignments for youth and staff when going
off grounds, staff were retrained on supervision requirements, and random
walk throughs are being completed at the facility to ensure staff are actively
4

supervising. The facility implemented all staff being retrained in reporting
requirements, and supervisors reviewing all incidents that occurred and
determine if a call to Centralized intake is required. The facility is currently
complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor the
CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
• Special Investigation 2025SIC0000657 with CAP approval date of
7/25/2025 was a result of suspected abuse and/or neglect not being
reported to Centralized Intake. The CAP mimicked the CAP for Special
Investigation 2025SIC0000644 as the two situations were within a short
period and the CAP had not yet been put into effect. The facility is currently
complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor the
CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
• Special Investigation 2025SIC0000854 with CAP approval date of
9/22/2025 was a result of a violation due to the facility not completing a final
incident report within 72 hours after the incident occurred. The facility
currently has a CAP to address incident reports being completed in
required timeframe however this incident was in relation to the
administration being out of the facility and not notified of the incidents
requiring approval in MiSACWIS. The facility additionally added action
steps to address this scenario, including designated approvers PTO and
business trios will be documented on the daily management report and the
AFA or Clinical Director will conduct the daily management meeting and
communicate with the FA and Compliance Director regarding submission
and approval of incident reports. The facility’s CAP was just approved and
DCWL will monitor the CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
• Special Investigation 2025SIC0000891 with CAP approval date of
9/22/2025 was a result of a violation due to a staff pushing a youth. The
facility immediately placed the staff on administrative leave pending the
investigation and since the staff has resigned from their position. The
facility indicated the staff is no longer employed and is not eligible for rehire.
The facility has retrained staff as well as implemented supervisors
completing walk throughs of the facility during shift to assess staff’s state of
mind and the milieu. The facility will be training all new staff on emotional
intelligence during onboarding as well to prevent future occurrences. The
facility’s CAP was just approved and DCWL will monitor the CAP
compliance with no noted concerns.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility’s
budget and the agency’s financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A

Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. Chief Administrator reported
since the last reporting period the facility has implemented several refresher
trainings and coaching sessions to address areas the facility was found in
noncompliance with which Chief Administrator indicated has yielded beneficial
results. Chief Administrator identified with several of the facilities CAP action steps
being incorporated into the shift log and documented by supervisors and leads has
helped create a documented line of accountability at the facility.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff members report feeling supported by administration. They reported being well
informed and trained on job expectations. Staff report the youth are well cared for
at the facility.
Youth interviews were conducted during the inspection. Youth reported they feel
safe and well cared for at Osceola Youth Center. Youth reported they feel
comfortable talking to staff and reported positive relationships with staff.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An onsite inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on September 23,
2025. There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
